item.title: Nvidia’s AI supremacy is a weapon that cuts both ways
item.description: While the chipmaker is the big winner from the booming technology, it is singularly exposed to changing expectations

item.title: The chipmaking pay revolution buys time, but will not solve scarcity of engineers
item.description: The same limited pool of young talent will keep being drawn on while global competition remains fierce

item.title: The tide is turning on China’s savings glut
item.description: Chinese policymakers are finally getting serious about boosting consumption

item.title: Target could yet win US retail’s ‘most improved’ prize
item.description: Retailer carries expectations low enough that even modest progress could produce meaningful upside

item.title: Zelenskyy needs to change the way he governs
item.description: Ukraine’s president must act decisively to repair trust lost over corruption scandal

item.title: Trade policy is central to the green transition
item.description: Governments must address the fact that imported ‘embodied’ emissions make up a large portion of their carbon footprints

item.title: Quantum computing needs its own industrial revolution
item.description: The path to scalable computers is paved with high-tech equipment not just high-impact academic papers

item.title: ‘Baby Shark’ still has teeth
item.description: Pinkfong’s success highlights how small, digital-native studios could disrupt the traditional media sector

item.title: The Labour government will deteriorate from here
item.description: Starmer and Reeves are unfit and their likeliest usurpers are worse

item.title: How the internet can rebuild trust
item.description: Algorithms and generative AI models that decide what billions of users see should be transparent

item.title: Will AI devour my pension?
item.description: Disruption to business models could leave corporate sponsors too stretched to cover DB scheme liabilities

item.title: Spain’s booming economy collides with a barren politics
item.description: Fifty years after the death of Franco, rancorous divisions in parliament have choked off policy debate

item.title: Time for anti-tech stocks
item.description: Staples are utterly hated, not that cheap and suddenly interesting

item.title: Europe’s battle for control of its money
item.description: Banks fear ECB plans for a digital euro will undermine a European alternative to Visa, Mastercard and PayPal

item.title: For scientists, the right questions are often the hardest
item.description: The most difficult problems can nurture the most talented researchers

item.title: Must I share money made before marriage in my divorce?
item.description: Recent trend of judges including all assets — before and after marriage — in financial settlements has raised concerns

item.description: The sector is expanding far beyond its giant IT service companies

item.description: Investors are acting as if a merger with rival Axalta is a non-starter

item.description: Algorithms ensure that people who click on scams are likely to see more of them

item.title: How much of the market is AI?
item.description: The S&P 500 is narrow, but not one-dimensional
